quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 11: Unit 4 Quiz 1
quiz.subtitle: 4.1: Sigma ($\sigma$) and Pi ($\pi$) Bonds
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Types of covalent bonds and their properties

questions.question: Which of the following describes the formation of a sigma ($\sigma$) bond?
options: Head-to-head overlap of orbitals along the internuclear axis
Side-to-side overlap of $p$ orbitals above and below the bond axis
The overlap of $d$ orbitals in a cloverleaf pattern
The attraction between a metal cation and a sea of electrons
questions.explanation: Sigma bonds are characterized by cylindrical symmetry and occur when orbitals overlap directly between the two nuclei.

questions.question: A pi ($\pi$) bond is characterized by:
options: Electron density concentrated above and below the internuclear axis
A single region of electron density directly between the nuclei
Higher bond strength than a sigma bond
The ability of the bonded atoms to rotate freely around the bond
questions.explanation: Pi bonds result from the side-to-side overlap of parallel $p$ orbitals, creating two regions of electron density.

questions.question: In a molecule of Ethene ($C_2H_4$), how many sigma and pi bonds are present in total?
options: 5 $\sigma$ and 1 $\pi$
4 $\sigma$ and 2 $\pi$
6 $\sigma$ and 0 $\pi$
3 $\sigma$ and 2 $\pi$
questions.explanation: There are four $C-H$ single bonds ($\sigma$), and one $C=C$ double bond (which consists of 1 $\sigma$ and 1 $\pi$). Total: $4+1=5 \sigma$ and $1 \pi$.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key difference between $\sigma$ and $\pi$ bonds regarding molecular rotation?
options: Free rotation is possible around $\sigma$ bonds, but restricted around $\pi$ bonds
Rotation is restricted for both $\sigma$ and $\pi$ bonds
Free rotation is possible for both $\sigma$ and $\pi$ bonds
$\pi$ bonds allow for faster rotation than $\sigma$ bonds
questions.explanation: Rotating a $\pi$ bond would break the side-to-side overlap of the $p$ orbitals, whereas rotating a $\sigma$ bond maintains the head-on overlap.

questions.question: How many pi ($\pi$) bonds are found in a triple bond?
questions.explanation: A triple bond always consists of one sigma bond and two pi bonds oriented at 90 degrees to each other.

questions.question: In the molecule Nitrogen ($N_2$), the bonding consists of:
options: One $\sigma$ bond and two $\pi$ bonds
Three $\sigma$ bonds
Two $\sigma$ bonds and one $\pi$ bond
Three $\pi$ bonds
questions.explanation: Nitrogen atoms are triple-bonded. The first bond is a sigma bond formed by $sp$ hybrids or $p_x$ orbitals, and the other two are pi bonds.

questions.question: Which bond is generally stronger and more stable?
options: A sigma ($\sigma$) bond
A pi ($\pi$) bond
They are equal in strength
The strength depends only on the atoms' masses
questions.explanation: Sigma bonds generally have greater orbital overlap than pi bonds, making them more stable and harder to break.

questions.question: Which type of orbitals can overlap to form a $\sigma$ bond?
options: All of these combinations can form a $\sigma$ bond
$s$ orbital with another $s$ orbital
$s$ orbital with a $p$ orbital
Two hybrid orbitals (e.g., $sp^3-sp^3$)
questions.explanation: Any orbital overlap that occurs head-on along the bond axis results in a sigma bond.

questions.question: In the molecule Formaldehyde ($CH_2O$), what is the nature of the $C=O$ bond?
options: One $\sigma$ bond and one $\pi$ bond
Two $\sigma$ bonds
Two $\pi$ bonds
A coordinate covalent bond
questions.explanation: The double bond between carbon and oxygen consists of one sigma bond and one pi bond.

questions.question: What happens to the $p$ orbitals when a pi bond is formed?
options: They overlap side-by-side and remain perpendicular to the $\sigma$ bond axis
They hybridize with $s$ orbitals to become $sp$ orbitals
They overlap head-on to form a stronger $\sigma$ bond
They disappear and are replaced by $d$ orbitals
questions.explanation: The $p$ orbitals involved in pi bonding are unhybridized and must be parallel to each other and perpendicular to the internuclear axis.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have a clear picture of how orbitals overlap in 3D space.
scoreMessages.70: Great job. You're distinguishing well between different types of covalent overlap.
scoreMessages.50: Good effort. Remember: 1st bond is $\sigma$, 2nd and 3rd are $\pi$.
scoreMessages.0: Review the visual difference between head-on and side-to-side orbital overlap.
